content:
You should modify your package.json to include the "type": "module" field and update the test script. Here's how to update it:

1. Add the "type": "module" line
2. Update the test script to run your test.js file

Your updated package.json should look like this:

```json
{
  "name": "communication-metrics",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "firebaseConfig.js",
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "test": "node test.js"
  },
  "keywords": [],
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "description": "",
  "dependencies": {
    "@emotion/react": "^11.14.0",
    "@emotion/styled": "^11.14.0",
    "@mui/icons-material": "^6.4.5",
    "@mui/material": "^6.4.5",
    "chart.js": "^4.4.8",
    "firebase": "^11.3.1",
    "react": "^19.0.0",
    "react-chartjs-2": "^5.3.0",
    "react-dom": "^19.0.0"
  }
}
```

You'll also need to add the OpenAI package:

```
npm install openai
```

The changes are:
1. Added "type": "module" - this allows you to use ES modules syntax (import/export)
2. Changed the test script to run your test.js file instead of the default error message

These changes will allow you to run your test using "npm run test" and ensure your JavaScript files can properly import/export modules.
